column1: Cedar Park is generally bisected north to south by U.S. Route 183. A bypass route
column3: also runs through Cedar Park and opened to traffic on March 15
column4: 2007. Major east–west routes include RM-1431/Whitestone Boulevard and Cypress Creek/Brushy Creek Road.

column1: Cedar Park is represented in Texas House of Representatives by Democrat John Bucy III. In the Texas State Senate
column2: Cedar Park is represented by Republican Charles Schwertner. In the United States House of Representatives

column1: Cedar Park is home to the Texas Stars of the American Hockey League and the Austin Spurs of the NBA G League both play home games at the H-E-B Center at Cedar Park.

column1: Cedar Park is served primarily by the Leander Independent School District
column2: and is home to the Cedar Park High School Timberwolves and the Vista Ridge High School Rangers. Cedar Park won its first football state championship on December 21
column3: 2012. The Timberwolves defeated Lancaster 17–7 at Cowboys Stadium in Arlington
column6: the Timberwolves won both state titles in Band and Football with the latter beating Frisco Lone Star for the Class 5a
column7: Division II state championship. Cedar Park High school is the only Texas high school to win UIL state titles in both band and football in the same year.

column1: The city is home to the Cypress Creek campus of Austin Community College
column2: which was significantly expanded in 2008 to accommodate the area's growing population.The Texas Psychological Association is located in the city.

column1: The H-E-B Center at Cedar Park (formerly known as Cedar Park Center) was completed in 2009 and hosts a wide array of live entertainment events. George Strait opened the Cedar Park Center as the first event at the Center on September 25
column2: 2009. The H-E-B Center is also home of the Texas Stars
column3: the AHL affiliate of the Dallas Stars
column5: the D-league affiliate of the San Antonio Spurs. The Center is located at the corner of New Hope Drive and 183A Toll Road.

column1: Before the arrival of European settlers in the 19th century
column2: the Cedar Park area was inhabited by Native American tribes including the Tonkawa
column4: and the Comanche. A paleo-American archaeological site (named the Wilson-Leonard site) was discovered in Cedar Park in 1983 that showed evidence of continual habitation of the area since circa 5000 BC.

column1: In the mid-19th century the community was known as Running Brushy
column2: named after a spring that formed the headwaters of a creek of the same name. In 1873 George and Harriet Cluck
column3: after having run cattle up the Chisholm Trail for many years
column4: bought 329 acres (1.33 km2) of land that included the Running Brushy spring. Their ranch formed the core of the community that would one day become Cedar Park.Ten years later
column5: the railroad came through. The Austin and Northwestern Railroad
column6: which connected the state capitol with the cities of Burnet and Lampasas to the north
column7: was finished in 1882 and passed through Running Brushy and the Cluck ranch. The community was at this point renamed Bruggerhoff
column8: after a railroad company official. However
column9: the name was generally disliked by locals
column10: being both hard to spell and pronounce. In 1887
column11: Emmett Cluck (son of George and Harriet) changed the community name to Cedar Park. In 1892
column13: 000 m2) was built near the train depot. Austinites would ride the train to Cedar Park for day trips to the park.Cedar Park changed little until the 1950s and 1960s when housing subdivisions began to be built
column14: spurred by the growth of nearby Austin. On February 24

column3: a strong and destructive F3 tornado struck the town. The tornado was one of 20 confirmed tornadoes that occurred during the 1997 Central Texas Tornado outbreak. It devastated the downtown area of the city
column4: killing one person and nearly destroying the Albertson's grocery store.
